items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: City’s 58 Fire Deaths in ’12 Are Lowest on Record
items.abstract: As civilian deaths drop, firefighters continue to be killed or wounded inside burning buildings where no civilians are killed.

items.title: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tech Design Comics and Artificial Intelligence Money
items.abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include Internet technologies spreading into more industries, which Web sites share what information and the latest iPhone bug.

items.title: Hurricane Cost City at Least $154 Million in Overtime
items.abstract: Eighty-one percent of the total went to the Police and Sanitation Departments alone, according to a report released Friday by the Independent Budget Office.

items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: City’s Delayed Traffic Study to Guide Regulation of Uber Vehicles
items.abstract: The study, which was originally due at the end of November, aimed to assess the ride-hailing service’s effects on traffic congestion in Manhattan.

items.title: Anger and Scrutiny Grow Over Poisoned Water in Michigan City
items.abstract: The state’s investigation into lead contamination of Flint’s drinking water follows the governor’s request that President Obama declare the problem a federal emergency.

items.title: Airbnb Takes Its Case to U.S. Mayors Conference
items.abstract: Having tried to mobilize the public in its favor, Airbnb offers to collect $200 million in hotel taxes for cities.

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: Shooting at Seattle Tent City Coincides With Mayor’s Homelessness Speech
items.abstract: Five people are shot, two of them fatally, in what the city authorities are calling a target attack, possibly linked to low-level drug activity.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: Traffic Deaths in New York City Drop to 200, a Record Low
items.abstract: Fewer people were killed last year in vehicle crashes, a sign that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan is working. But pedestrian deaths increased.

items.title: Judge Blocks New York City Law Aimed at Curbing Airbnb Rentals
items.abstract: The law was intended to prevent apartments from being used as illegal hotels. The decision could aid home-sharing services’ fights in other cities.

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: New York Plans to Install ‘Vending Machines’ With Anti-Overdose Drugs
items.abstract: In addition to naloxone, a medication used to reverse opioid overdoses, the machines will distribute free syringes, toiletries and safe-sex kits.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: New York City sees ‘a glimmer of hope’ as virus cases level off, but they are still rising upstate.
items.abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul said new coronavirus cases in New York City were beginning to plateau. The state will stop requiring counties to trace contacts, freeing public health resources for other needs.

items.title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
items.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.
